sn12.56:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, suppose there was a great tree.

sn12.56:1.3.pli: Tassa yāni ceva mūlāni adhogamāni, yāni ca tiriyaṅgamāni, sabbāni tāni uddhaṃ ojaṃ abhiharanti.
sn12.56:1.3.eng: And its roots going downwards and across all draw the sap upwards.

sn12.56:1.4.pli: Evañhi so, bhikkhave, mahārukkho tadāhāro tadupādāno ciraṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ tiṭṭheyya.
sn12.56:1.4.eng: Fed and fuelled by that, the great tree would stand for a long time.

sn12.56:1.5.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, upādāniyesu dhammesu assādānupassino viharato taṇhā pavaḍḍhati.
sn12.56:1.5.eng: In the same way, there are things that fuel grasping. When you concentrate on the gratification provided by these things, your craving grows.

sn12.56:1.6.eng: Craving is a requirement for grasping. …

sn12.56:1.7.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn12.56:2.1.eng: Suppose there was a great tree.

sn12.56:2.2.eng: Then a person comes along with a spade and basket.

sn12.56:2.3.pli: So taṃ rukkhaṃ mūle chindeyya, mūle chetvā palikhaṇeyya, palikhaṇitvā mūlāni uddhareyya …pe…
sn12.56:2.3.eng: They’d cut the tree down at the roots, dig them up, and pull them out, down to the fibers and stems.

sn12.56:2.4.eng: They’d cut the tree apart, cut up the parts, and chop it into splinters. They’d dry the splinters in the wind and sun, burn them with fire, and reduce them to ashes. Then they’d winnow the ashes in a strong wind, or glide them down a swift stream.

sn12.56:2.5.pli: Evañhi so, bhikkhave, mahārukkho ucchinnamūlo assa tālāvatthukato anabhāvaṅkato āyatiṃ anuppādadhammo.
sn12.56:2.5.eng: In this way the great tree is cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.

sn12.56:2.6.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, upādāniyesu dhammesu ādīnavānupassino viharato taṇhā nirujjhati.
sn12.56:2.6.eng: In the same way, there are things that fuel grasping. When you concentrate on the drawbacks of these things, your craving ceases.

sn12.56:2.8.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.”

sn12.57:1.2.pli: “Saṃyojaniyesu, bhikkhave, dhammesu assādānupassino viharato taṇhā pavaḍḍhati.
sn12.57:1.2.eng: “There are things that tighten the fetters. When you concentrate on the gratification provided by these things, your craving grows.

sn12.57:1.3.eng: Craving is a requirement for grasping. …

sn12.57:1.4.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn12.57:2.2.pli: Tassa puriso kālena kālaṃ mūlāni palimajjeyya kālena kālaṃ paṃsuṃ dadeyya, kālena kālaṃ udakaṃ dadeyya.
sn12.57:2.2.eng: And from time to time someone would clear around the roots, supply soil, and water it.

sn12.57:2.3.pli: Evañhi so, bhikkhave, taruṇo rukkho tadāhāro tadupādāno vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjeyya.
sn12.57:2.3.eng: Fed and fuelled by that, the sapling would grow, increase, and mature.

sn12.57:2.4.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, saṃyojaniyesu dhammesu assādānupassino viharato taṇhā pavaḍḍhati.
sn12.57:2.4.eng: In the same way, there are things that tighten the fetters. When you concentrate on the gratification provided by these things, your craving grows.

sn12.57:2.5.eng: Craving is a requirement for grasping. …

sn12.57:2.6.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn12.57:3.1.pli: Saṃyojaniyesu, bhikkhave, dhammesu ādīnavānupassino viharato taṇhā nirujjhati.
sn12.57:3.1.eng: There are things that tighten the fetters. When you concentrate on the drawbacks of these things, your craving ceases.

sn12.57:3.3.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.

sn12.57:4.2.eng: Then a person comes along with a spade and basket. …

sn12.57:4.3.eng: They’d cut the sapling apart, cut up the parts, and chop it into splinters. They’d dry the splinters in the wind and sun, burn them with fire, and reduce them to ashes. Then they’d winnow the ashes in a strong wind, or glide them down a swift stream.

sn12.57:4.4.pli: Evañhi so, bhikkhave, taruṇo rukkho ucchinnamūlo assa tālāvatthukato anabhāvaṅkato āyatiṃ anuppādadhammo.
sn12.57:4.4.eng: In this way the sapling is cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.

sn12.57:4.5.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, saṃyojaniyesu dhammesu ādīnavānupassino viharato taṇhā nirujjhati.
sn12.57:4.5.eng: In the same way, there are things that tighten the fetters. When you concentrate on the drawbacks of these things, your craving ceases.

sn12.57:4.7.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.”

sn12.58:1.2.pli: “Saṃyojaniyesu, bhikkhave, dhammesu assādānupassino viharato nāmarūpassa avakkanti hoti.
sn12.58:1.2.eng: “There are things that tighten the fetters. When you concentrate on the gratification provided by these things, name and form are conceived.

sn12.58:1.3.eng: Name and form are requirements for the six sense fields. …

sn12.58:1.4.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn12.58:2.1.eng: Suppose there was a great tree.

sn12.58:2.2.pli: Tassa yāni ceva mūlāni adhogamāni, yāni ca tiriyaṅgamāni, sabbāni tāni uddhaṃ ojaṃ abhiharanti.
sn12.58:2.2.eng: And its roots going downwards and across all draw the sap upwards.

sn12.58:2.3.pli: Evañhi so, bhikkhave, mahārukkho tadāhāro tadupādāno ciraṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ tiṭṭheyya.
sn12.58:2.3.eng: Fed and fuelled by that, the great tree would stand for a long time.

sn12.58:2.4.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, saṃyojaniyesu dhammesu assādānupassino viharato nāmarūpassa avakkanti hoti …pe….
sn12.58:2.4.eng: In the same way, there are things that tighten the fetters. When you concentrate on the gratification provided by these things, name and form are conceived. …

sn12.58:3.1.pli: Saṃyojaniyesu, bhikkhave, dhammesu ādīnavānupassino viharato nāmarūpassa avakkanti na hoti.
sn12.58:3.1.eng: There are things that tighten the fetters. When you concentrate on the drawbacks of these things, name and form are not conceived.

sn12.58:3.2.eng: When name and form cease, the six sense fields cease. …

sn12.58:3.3.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.

sn12.58:4.1.eng: Suppose there was a great tree.

sn12.58:4.2.eng: Then a person comes along with a spade and basket. …

sn12.58:4.3.eng: In this way the great tree is cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.

sn12.58:4.4.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, saṃyojaniyesu dhammesu ādīnavānupassino viharato nāmarūpassa avakkanti na hoti.
sn12.58:4.4.eng: In the same way, there are things that tighten the fetters. When you concentrate on the drawbacks of these things, name and form are not conceived.

sn12.58:4.5.eng: When name and form cease, the six sense fields cease. …

sn12.58:4.6.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.”

sn12.59:1.2.pli: “Saṃyojaniyesu, bhikkhave, dhammesu assādānupassino viharato viññāṇassa avakkanti hoti.
sn12.59:1.2.eng: “There are things that tighten the fetters. When you concentrate on the gratification provided by these things, consciousness is conceived.

sn12.59:1.3.eng: Consciousness is a requirement for name and form. …

sn12.59:1.4.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn12.59:2.1.eng: Suppose there was a great tree.

sn12.59:2.2.eng: And its roots going downwards and across all draw the sap upwards. …

sn12.59:2.3.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, saṃyojaniyesu dhammesu assādānupassino viharato viññāṇassa avakkanti hoti …pe….
sn12.59:2.3.eng: In the same way, there are things that tighten the fetters. When you concentrate on the gratification provided by these things, consciousness is conceived. …

sn12.59:3.1.pli: Saṃyojaniyesu, bhikkhave, dhammesu ādīnavānupassino viharato viññāṇassa avakkanti na hoti.
sn12.59:3.1.eng: There are things that tighten the fetters. When you concentrate on the drawbacks of these things, consciousness is not conceived.

sn12.59:3.2.eng: When consciousness ceases, name and form cease. …

sn12.59:3.3.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.

sn12.59:4.1.eng: Suppose there was a great tree.

sn12.59:4.2.eng: Then a person comes along with a spade and basket. …

sn12.59:4.3.eng: In this way the great tree is cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.

sn12.59:4.4.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, saṃyojaniyesu dhammesu ādīnavānupassino viharato viññāṇassa avakkanti na hoti.
sn12.59:4.4.eng: In the same way, there are things that tighten the fetters. When you concentrate on the drawbacks of these things, consciousness is not conceived.

sn12.59:4.5.eng: When consciousness ceases, name and form cease. …

sn12.59:4.6.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.”

sn12.6:1.1.eng: “Vessabhū, the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha …”

sn12.60:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kurūsu viharati kammāsadhammaṃ nāma kurūnaṃ nigamo.
sn12.60:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Kurus, near the Kuru town named Kammāsadamma.
sn12.60:1.1.comm: This Nidānasutta opens in a way practically identical to the Mahānidānasutta (DN 15). However, after the introduction it merely recapitulates the teachings from the previous discourses, unlike the Mahānidānasutta which introduces a dazzling range of unique perspectives. It is hardly possible that Ānanda would make the same mistake twice, so it seems likely that the present discourse is an artificial composite.

sn12.60:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn12.60:1.2.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to the Buddha:

sn12.60:1.4.pli: Yāva gambhīro cāyaṃ, bhante, paṭiccasamuppādo gambhīrāvabhāso ca, atha ca pana me uttānakuttānako viya khāyatī”ti.
sn12.60:1.4.eng: in that this dependent origination is deep and appears deep, yet to me it seems as plain as can be.”

sn12.60:2.2.pli: Gambhīro cāyaṃ, ānanda, paṭiccasamuppādo gambhīrāvabhāso ca.
sn12.60:2.2.eng: This dependent origination is deep and appears deep.

sn12.60:2.3.pli: Etassa, ānanda, dhammassa ananubodhā appaṭivedhā evamayaṃ pajā tantākulakajātā kulagaṇṭhikajātā muñjapabbajabhūtā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ saṃsāraṃ nātivattati.
sn12.60:2.3.eng: It is because of not understanding and not penetrating this teaching that this population has become tangled like string, knotted like a ball of thread, and matted like rushes and reeds, and it doesn’t escape the places of loss, the bad places, the underworld, transmigration.

sn12.60:3.1.pli: Upādāniyesu, ānanda, dhammesu assādānupassino viharato taṇhā pavaḍḍhati.
sn12.60:3.1.eng: There are things that fuel grasping. When you concentrate on the gratification provided by these things, your craving grows.

sn12.60:3.2.eng: Craving is a requirement for grasping.

sn12.60:3.3.eng: Grasping is a requirement for continued existence.

sn12.60:3.4.eng: Continued existence is a requirement for rebirth.

sn12.60:3.5.eng: Rebirth is a requirement for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.

sn12.60:3.6.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn12.60:4.1.eng: Suppose there was a great tree.

sn12.60:4.2.pli: Tassa yāni ceva mūlāni adhogamāni, yāni ca tiriyaṅgamāni, sabbāni tāni uddhaṃ ojaṃ abhiharanti.
sn12.60:4.2.eng: And its roots going downwards and across all draw the sap upwards.

sn12.60:4.3.pli: Evañhi so, ānanda, mahārukkho tadāhāro tadupādāno ciraṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ tiṭṭheyya.
sn12.60:4.3.eng: Fed and fuelled by that, the great tree would stand for a long time.

sn12.60:4.4.pli: Evameva kho, ānanda, upādāniyesu dhammesu assādānupassino viharato taṇhā pavaḍḍhati.
sn12.60:4.4.eng: In the same way, there are things that fuel grasping. When you concentrate on the gratification provided by these things, your craving grows.

sn12.60:4.5.eng: Craving is a requirement for grasping.

sn12.60:4.6.eng: Grasping is a requirement for continued existence. …

sn12.60:4.7.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn12.60:5.1.pli: Upādāniyesu, ānanda, dhammesu ādīnavānupassino viharato taṇhā nirujjhati.
sn12.60:5.1.eng: There are things that fuel grasping. When you concentrate on the drawbacks of these things, your craving ceases.

sn12.60:5.3.eng: When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases. …

sn12.60:5.4.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.

sn12.60:6.1.eng: Suppose there was a great tree.

sn12.60:6.2.eng: Then a person comes along with a spade and basket.

sn12.60:6.3.pli: So taṃ rukkhaṃ mūle chindeyya, mūle chetvā palikhaṇeyya, palikhaṇitvā mūlāni uddhareyya antamaso usīranāḷimattānipi.
sn12.60:6.3.eng: They’d cut the tree down at the roots, dig them up, and pull them out, down to the fibers and stems.

sn12.60:6.4.eng: Then they’d split the tree apart, cut up the parts, and chop it into splinters. They’d dry the splinters in the wind and sun, burn them with fire, and reduce them to ashes. Then they’d winnow the ashes in a strong wind, or float them away down a swift stream.

sn12.60:6.6.pli: phāletvā sakalikaṃ sakalikaṃ kareyya, sakalikaṃ sakalikaṃ karitvā vātātape visoseyya, vātātape visosetvā agginā ḍaheyya, agginā ḍahetvā masiṃ kareyya, masiṃ karitvā mahāvāte vā ophuṇeyya, nadiyā vā sīghasotāya pavāheyya.

sn12.60:6.7.pli: Evañhi so, ānanda, mahārukkho ucchinnamūlo assa tālāvatthukato anabhāvaṅkato āyatiṃ anuppādadhammo.
sn12.60:6.7.eng: In this way the great tree is cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.

sn12.60:6.8.pli: Evameva kho, ānanda, upādāniyesu dhammesu ādīnavānupassino viharato taṇhā nirujjhati.
sn12.60:6.8.eng: In the same way, there are things that fuel grasping. When you concentrate on the drawbacks of these things, your craving ceases.

sn12.60:6.10.eng: When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases.

sn12.60:6.11.eng: When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases.

sn12.60:6.12.eng: When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease.

sn12.60:6.13.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.”

sn12.61:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme …
sn12.61:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. …

sn12.61:1.3.pli: “assutavā, bhikkhave, puthujjano imasmiṃ cātumahābhūtikasmiṃ kāyasmiṃ nibbindeyyapi virajjeyyapi vimucceyyapi.
sn12.61:1.3.eng: “Mendicants, an unlearned ordinary person might become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed from this body made up of the four principal states.
sn12.61:1.3.comm: The technical term “body made up of the four principal states” clarifies that it is the material body spoken of here, rather than, say, the “mental body” (DN 15:20.2).

sn12.61:1.5.pli: Dissati, bhikkhave, imassa cātumahābhūtikassa kāyassa ācayopi apacayopi ādānampi nikkhepanampi.
sn12.61:1.5.eng: This body made up of the four principal states is seen to accumulate and disperse, to be taken up and laid to rest.

sn12.61:1.6.pli: Tasmā tatrāssutavā puthujjano nibbindeyyapi virajjeyyapi vimucceyyapi.
sn12.61:1.6.eng: That’s why an unlearned ordinary person might become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed from it.
sn12.61:1.6.comm: A number of non-Buddhist religious teachers were said to be “free of desire for sensual pleasures” through developing absorption meditation (AN 6.54:13.7, AN 7.66:11.1). This would probably include the Buddha’s former teachers. Such freedom is temporary, however, as without severing the root-level attachments the desire will eventually resurface.

sn12.61:2.1.pli: Yañca kho etaṃ, bhikkhave, vuccati cittaṃ itipi, mano itipi, viññāṇaṃ itipi, tatrāssutavā puthujjano nālaṃ nibbindituṃ nālaṃ virajjituṃ nālaṃ vimuccituṃ.
sn12.61:2.1.eng: But an unlearned ordinary person is unable to become disillusioned, dispassionate, or freed from that which is called ‘mind’ and also ‘sentience’ and also ‘consciousness’.
sn12.61:2.1.comm: The terms “mind” (citta), “sentience” (mano), and “consciousness” (viññāṇa) are broadly synonymous and in many cases may be substituted for one another. Nonetheless, they each have a particular context in which they predominate. Citta is to be developed, in which respect it pertains to the fourth noble truth, the path. Mano, which I translate here as “sentience” for the sake of disambiguation, is often used in the active sense of the deeds done by the mind, pertaining to the second noble truth, the origin of suffering. Viññāṇa is the key factor in the experince of suffering, pertaining to the first noble truth.

sn12.61:2.3.pli: Dīgharattañhetaṃ, bhikkhave, assutavato puthujjanassa ajjhositaṃ mamāyitaṃ parāmaṭṭhaṃ:
sn12.61:2.3.eng: Because for a long time they’ve been attached to it, thought of it as their own, and mistaken it:

sn12.61:2.4.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self.’
sn12.61:2.4.comm: This view is expressed at DN 1:2.13.4.

sn12.61:2.5.pli: Tasmā tatrāssutavā puthujjano nālaṃ nibbindituṃ nālaṃ virajjituṃ nālaṃ vimuccituṃ.
sn12.61:2.5.eng: That’s why an unlearned ordinary person is unable to become disillusioned, dispassionate, or freed from it.

sn12.61:3.1.pli: Varaṃ, bhikkhave, assutavā puthujjano imaṃ cātumahābhūtikaṃ kāyaṃ attato upagaccheyya, na tveva cittaṃ.
sn12.61:3.1.eng: But an unlearned ordinary person would be better off taking this body made up of the four principal states to be their self, rather than the mind.

sn12.61:3.3.pli: Dissatāyaṃ, bhikkhave, cātumahābhūtiko kāyo ekampi vassaṃ tiṭṭhamāno dvepi vassāni tiṭṭhamāno tīṇipi vassāni tiṭṭhamāno cattāripi vassāni tiṭṭhamāno pañcapi vassāni tiṭṭhamāno dasapi vassāni tiṭṭhamāno vīsatipi vassāni tiṭṭhamāno tiṃsampi vassāni tiṭṭhamāno cattārīsampi vassāni tiṭṭhamāno paññāsampi vassāni tiṭṭhamāno vassasatampi tiṭṭhamāno, bhiyyopi tiṭṭhamāno.
sn12.61:3.3.eng: This body made up of the four principal states is seen to last for a year, or for two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, or a hundred years, or even longer.

sn12.61:4.1.pli: Yañca kho etaṃ, bhikkhave, vuccati cittaṃ itipi, mano itipi, viññāṇaṃ itipi, taṃ rattiyā ca divasassa ca aññadeva uppajjati aññaṃ nirujjhati.
sn12.61:4.1.eng: But that which is called ‘mind’ and also ‘sentience’ and also ‘consciousness’ arises as one thing and ceases as another all day and all night.
sn12.61:4.1.comm: Note that impermanence is described as constantly changing during the day rather than in terms of momentariness, which is not found in the Suttas.

sn12.61:4.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, makkaṭo araññe pavane caramāno sākhaṃ gaṇhati, taṃ muñcitvā aññaṃ gaṇhati, taṃ muñcitvā aññaṃ gaṇhati;
sn12.61:4.2.eng: It’s like a monkey moving through the forest. It grabs hold of one branch, lets it go, and grabs another; then it lets that go and grabs yet another.
sn12.61:4.2.comm: This is an early source for the idiom “monkey mind”. See also Thag 2.3:2.1, Snp 4.4:4.3, and especially Thag 19.1:21.3.

sn12.61:4.3.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, yamidaṃ vuccati cittaṃ itipi, mano itipi, viññāṇaṃ itipi, taṃ rattiyā ca divasassa ca aññadeva uppajjati aññaṃ nirujjhati.
sn12.61:4.3.eng: In the same way, that which is called ‘mind’ and also ‘sentience’ and also ‘consciousness’ arises as one thing and ceases as another all day and all night.

sn12.61:5.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako paṭiccasamuppādaṃyeva sādhukaṃ yoniso manasi karoti:
sn12.61:5.1.eng: In this case, a learned noble disciple carefully and rationally applies the mind to dependent origination itself:

sn12.61:5.2.pli: ‘iti imasmiṃ sati idaṃ hoti, imassuppādā idaṃ uppajjati;
sn12.61:5.2.eng: ‘When this exists, this comes to be; due to the arising of this, this arises.

sn12.61:5.3.pli: imasmiṃ asati idaṃ na hoti, imassa nirodhā idaṃ nirujjhati—
sn12.61:5.3.eng: When this doesn’t exist, this doesn’t come to be; due to the cessation of this, this ceases. That is:

sn12.61:5.4.eng: Ignorance is a requirement for choices.

sn12.61:5.5.eng: Choices are a requirement for consciousness. …

sn12.61:5.6.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn12.61:5.7.eng: When ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, choices cease.

sn12.61:5.9.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.’

sn12.61:6.1.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako rūpasmimpi nibbindati, vedanāyapi nibbindati, saññāyapi nibbindati, saṅkhāresupi nibbindati, viññāṇasmimpi nibbindati;
sn12.61:6.1.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn12.61:6.2.pli: nibbindaṃ virajjati, virāgā vimuccati, vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti.
sn12.61:6.2.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

sn12.61:6.3.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
sn12.61:6.3.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn12.62:1.2.pli: “Assutavā, bhikkhave, puthujjano imasmiṃ cātumahābhūtikasmiṃ kāyasmiṃ nibbindeyyapi virajjeyyapi vimucceyyapi.
sn12.62:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, an unlearned ordinary person might become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed from this body made up of the four principal states.

sn12.62:1.4.pli: Dissati, bhikkhave, imassa cātumahābhūtikassa kāyassa ācayopi apacayopi ādānampi nikkhepanampi.
sn12.62:1.4.eng: This body made up of the four principal states is seen to accumulate and disperse, to be taken up and laid to rest.

sn12.62:1.5.pli: Tasmā tatrāssutavā puthujjano nibbindeyyapi virajjeyyapi vimucceyyapi.
sn12.62:1.5.eng: That’s why an unlearned ordinary person might become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed from it.

sn12.62:1.6.pli: Yañca kho etaṃ, bhikkhave, vuccati cittaṃ itipi, mano itipi, viññāṇaṃ itipi, tatrāssutavā puthujjano nālaṃ nibbindituṃ nālaṃ virajjituṃ nālaṃ vimuccituṃ.
sn12.62:1.6.eng: But an unlearned ordinary person is unable to become disillusioned, dispassionate, or freed from that which is called ‘mind’ and also ‘sentience’ and also ‘consciousness’.

sn12.62:1.8.pli: Dīgharattañhetaṃ, bhikkhave, assutavato puthujjanassa ajjhositaṃ mamāyitaṃ parāmaṭṭhaṃ:
sn12.62:1.8.eng: Because for a long time they’ve been attached to it, thought of it as their own, and mistaken it:

sn12.62:1.9.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self.’

sn12.62:1.10.pli: Tasmā tatrāssutavā puthujjano nālaṃ nibbindituṃ nālaṃ virajjituṃ nālaṃ vimuccituṃ.
sn12.62:1.10.eng: That’s why an unlearned ordinary person is unable to become disillusioned, dispassionate, or freed from it.

sn12.62:2.1.pli: Varaṃ, bhikkhave, assutavā puthujjano imaṃ cātumahābhūtikaṃ kāyaṃ attato upagaccheyya, na tveva cittaṃ.
sn12.62:2.1.eng: But an unlearned ordinary person would be better off taking this body made up of the four principal states to be their self, rather than the mind.

sn12.62:2.3.pli: Dissatāyaṃ, bhikkhave, cātumahābhūtiko kāyo ekampi vassaṃ tiṭṭhamāno dvepi vassāni tiṭṭhamāno tīṇipi vassāni tiṭṭhamāno cattāripi vassāni tiṭṭhamāno pañcapi vassāni tiṭṭhamāno dasapi vassāni tiṭṭhamāno vīsatipi vassāni tiṭṭhamāno tiṃsampi vassāni tiṭṭhamāno cattārīsampi vassāni tiṭṭhamāno paññāsampi vassāni tiṭṭhamāno vassasatampi tiṭṭhamāno, bhiyyopi tiṭṭhamāno.
sn12.62:2.3.eng: This body made up of the four principal states is seen to last for a year, or for two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, or a hundred years, or even longer.

sn12.62:2.4.pli: Yañca kho etaṃ, bhikkhave, vuccati cittaṃ itipi, mano itipi, viññāṇaṃ itipi, taṃ rattiyā ca divasassa ca aññadeva uppajjati aññaṃ nirujjhati.
sn12.62:2.4.eng: But that which is called ‘mind’ and also ‘sentience’ and also ‘consciousness’ arises as one thing and ceases as another all day and all night.

sn12.62:3.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako paṭiccasamuppādaṃyeva sādhukaṃ yoniso manasi karoti:
sn12.62:3.1.eng: In this case, a learned noble disciple carefully and rationally applies the mind to dependent origination itself:
sn12.62:3.1.comm: Here the abstract principle stands for the full set of links, which are not stated in this discourse.

sn12.62:3.2.pli: ‘iti imasmiṃ sati idaṃ hoti, imassuppādā idaṃ uppajjati;
sn12.62:3.2.eng: ‘When this exists, this comes to be; due to the arising of this, this arises.

sn12.62:3.3.pli: imasmiṃ asati idaṃ na hoti, imassa nirodhā idaṃ nirujjhatī’ti.
sn12.62:3.3.eng: When this doesn’t exist, this doesn’t come to be; due to the cessation of this, this ceases.’

sn12.62:3.4.pli: Sukhavedaniyaṃ, bhikkhave, phassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati sukhavedanā.
sn12.62:3.4.eng: Pleasant feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as pleasant.
sn12.62:3.4.comm: That is to say, certain kinds of contact are prone to create pleasant feelings, such as the contact experienced with a delicious taste, or in absorption.

sn12.62:3.5.pli: Tasseva sukhavedaniyassa phassassa nirodhā yaṃ tajjaṃ vedayitaṃ sukhavedaniyaṃ phassaṃ paṭicca uppannā sukhavedanā sā nirujjhati sā vūpasammati.
sn12.62:3.5.eng: With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as pleasant, the corresponding pleasant feeling ceases and stops.

sn12.62:3.6.pli: Dukkhavedaniyaṃ, bhikkhave, phassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dukkhavedanā.
sn12.62:3.6.eng: Painful feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as painful.

sn12.62:3.7.pli: Tasseva dukkhavedaniyassa phassassa nirodhā yaṃ tajjaṃ vedayitaṃ dukkhavedaniyaṃ phassaṃ paṭicca uppannā dukkhavedanā sā nirujjhati sā vūpasammati.
sn12.62:3.7.eng: With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as painful, the corresponding painful feeling ceases and stops.

sn12.62:3.8.pli: Adukkhamasukhavedaniyaṃ, bhikkhave, phassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati adukkhamasukhavedanā.
sn12.62:3.8.eng: Neutral feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as neutral.

sn12.62:3.9.pli: Tasseva adukkhamasukhavedaniyassa phassassa nirodhā yaṃ tajjaṃ vedayitaṃ adukkhamasukhavedaniyaṃ phassaṃ paṭicca uppannā adukkhamasukhavedanā sā nirujjhati sā vūpasammati.
sn12.62:3.9.eng: With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as neutral, the corresponding neutral feeling ceases and stops.

sn12.62:4.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, dvinnaṃ kaṭṭhānaṃ saṅghaṭṭanasamodhānā usmā jāyati tejo abhinibbattati. Tesaṃyeva dvinnaṃ kaṭṭhānaṃ nānākatavinibbhogā yā tajjā usmā sā nirujjhati sā vūpasammati;
sn12.62:4.1.eng: When you rub two sticks together, heat is generated and fire is produced. But when you part the sticks and lay them aside, any corresponding heat ceases and stops.

sn12.62:4.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, sukhavedaniyaṃ phassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati sukhavedanā.
sn12.62:4.2.eng: In the same way, pleasant feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as pleasant.

sn12.62:4.3.pli: Tasseva sukhavedaniyassa phassassa nirodhā yaṃ tajjaṃ vedayitaṃ sukhavedaniyaṃ phassaṃ paṭicca uppannā sukhavedanā sā nirujjhati sā vūpasammati …pe…
sn12.62:4.3.eng: With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as pleasant, the corresponding pleasant feeling ceases and stops.

sn12.62:4.5.eng: Neutral feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as neutral.

sn12.62:4.6.pli: Tasseva adukkhamasukhavedaniyassa phassassa nirodhā yaṃ tajjaṃ vedayitaṃ adukkhamasukhavedaniyaṃ phassaṃ paṭicca uppannā adukkhamasukhavedanā sā nirujjhati sā vūpasammati.
sn12.62:4.6.eng: With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as neutral, the corresponding neutral feeling ceases and stops.

sn12.62:5.1.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako phassepi nibbindati, vedanāyapi nibbindati, saññāyapi nibbindati, saṅkhāresupi nibbindati, viññāṇasmimpi nibbindati;
sn12.62:5.1.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with contact, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
sn12.62:5.1.comm: This sentence lists “contact” where, in the five aggregates, we would expect “form”. That’s because here it stands for the contact experienced through the senses, starting with the “eye”, which is included in “form”. A similar structure is found elsewhere, showing the linkage between these teaching frameworks (SN 35.121:15.1).

sn12.62:5.2.pli: nibbindaṃ virajjati, virāgā vimuccati, vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti.
sn12.62:5.2.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

sn12.62:5.3.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
sn12.62:5.3.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”
